Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: If your organization does not allow users to access the Office Store (AppSource), administrators can configure Centralized Deployment to control which users or groups can continue accessing the Excel add-in.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Enabling Centralized Deployment affects features that use the Excel add-in, such as the ‘Edit in Excel’ action, but has no impact on other Excel-related features and does not affect permissions assigned to users in Business Central.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Centralized Deployment requires configuring both Microsoft 365 and Business Central. Choose Next to get started.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Let’s start by configuring app settings in Microsoft 365. You must be part of the Office apps admin role or Global admin role to do this.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: 2. Choose ‘Get apps’, then search for and add ‘Microsoft Dynamics Office Add-in´.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: 3. Follow the deployment instructions and choose who has access to the add-in.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: After the add-in has been deployed, choose Next to configure Business Central.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Users of this environment can either receive the add-in through Centralized Deployment or through individual acquisition from the Office Store, but not both.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Enabling Centralized Deployment on this environment requires users to have their identity assigned to the add-in in Microsoft 365 as specified in the previous step to continue using the Edit in Excel feature.

Properties.Value: Specifies the use of Centralized Deployment on this environment.

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: Welcome to the Data Classification Assisted Setup Guide

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Data classification is an important part of protecting the privacy of personal and sensitive data, and is often required by data privacy laws. Classification can make it easier to retrieve personal data, for example, in response to a request, and it can add another layer of protection. This guide helps you classify the sensitivity of the data in tables and fields.

Controls.Name: Welcome to the Data Classification Assisted Setup Guide

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: - Sensitive - Private data, such as political or religious beliefs.

Controls.Name: - Sensitive - Private data, such as political or religious beliefs.

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: - Personal - Any data that can be used to identify someone.

Controls.Name: - Personal - Any data that can be used to identify someone.

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: - Company Confidential - Business data that you do not want to expose. For example, ledger entries.

Controls.Name: - Company Confidential - Business data that you do not want to expose. For example, ledger entries.

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: - Normal - Data that does not belong to other classifications.

Controls.Name: - Normal - Data that does not belong to other classifications.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: Microsoft is providing this Data Classification feature as a matter of convenience only. It's your responsibility to classify the data appropriately and comply with any laws and regulations that are applicable to you. Microsoft disclaims all responsibility towards any claims related to your classification of the data.

Properties.Name: Caption
Properties.Value: - Sharing data with a partner who is classifying data for you.

Controls.Name: - Sharing data with a partner who is classifying data for you.

Controls.Name: - Importing the classifications from another company.

Properties.Name: ToolTip

Properties.Name: ToolTip
Properties.Value: Specifies that you want to classify data sensitivity yourself. If you choose this option, you can specify data sensitivity for individual fields and data subjects. Note that this includes only data related to setups, posting, templates, and data subjects. There are fields that you must classify either in the Classification Worksheet page or in Excel.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText
Properties.Value: You can also view lists of tables and fields and manually classify your data.

Properties.Name: InstructionalText

These classifications apply only to fields that are currently Unclassified. We recommend that you review the fields before you apply the classifications.

Sensitive: Information about a data subject's racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious beliefs, involvement with trade unions, physical or mental health, sexuality, or details about criminal offenses. Personal: Information that can be used to identify a data subject, either directly or in combination with other data or information. Confidential: Business data that you use for accounting or other business purposes, and do not want to expose to other entities. For example, this might include ledger entries. Normal: General data that does not belong to any other categories.
